contents.context:
The South Korean government once again urged the public to practice social distancing measures in daily life as the country continues to report community-based transmissions.
As of Saturday, the COVID-19 cluster infection linked to a Coupang distribution center in Bucheon has reached 1-hundred-8 in total, 35 of whom were infected through contact with the center's employees.
The total number of confirmed cases related to the Itaewon district now stands at 2-hundred-69, after adding 3 new cases on Saturday.
While South Korea's daily confirmed cases declined for the third day in a row to 39, officials are still emphasizing the need for people's participation in daily quarantine measures.


"There are still cases that are difficult to track the link of infection, and the cluster infection linked to the Bucheon logistics center poses a high risk of community transmissions."

The official added that it is crucial to take extra care, especially in the metropolitan area where there are many places that are vulnerable to further infections such as health care and religious facilities.
Being cooperative with the epidemiological surveys and undergoing testing if showing any symptoms were also emphasized.
Yet, the Deputy Director also said that there have been some successful cases of containing the further spread of the virus from cluster infections.
Mentioning earlier cases that originated from a religious group and a large clinical facility, he assured that the so-called "second wave" of infections can be prevented with sufficient preparation.
Kim Sung-min, Arirang News
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korean gov't emphasizes distancing in daily life despite decline in newly confirmed cases
Updated: 2020-05-30 15:50:37 KST

contents.context:
We begin with the COVID-19 situation here in the nation.
South Korea has confirmed 39 new cases on Saturday.
75 percent of them are from the metropolitan area, but the rest emerged from other big cities, including Daegu and Busan.
That takes the total number of cases to 11-thousand 441.
With no additional deaths, the death toll remains at 269.
South Korea's Central Disaster and Safety Countermeasure Headquarters on Saturday has once again urged citizens to follow quarantine measuresincluding refraining from visiting regularly crowded places like going to shopping malls.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea sees 39 new COVID-19 cases on Sat., majority from metropolitan area
Updated: 2020-05-30 12:09:00 KST

contents.context:
Seoul is holding a five-day global summit online next week, focusing on the challenges of the post-COVID-19 era and sharing the know-hows in their pandemic response.
From climate change and quarantine measures to education and welfare a total of ten topics will be up for discussion by officials, experts, scholars and the mayors of more than 40 cities around the world.
The city has set up a web conference studio with LED screens.
The video conference will be livestreamed online by the Seoul city government’s YouTube channels as well as by Arirang TV, with simultaneous interpretations in English and Korean.
Reporter : jychoi@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Seoul to hold global summit on post-coronavirus era with mayors of 40 cities
Updated: 2020-05-30 09:26:41 KST

contents.context:
South Korea has seen a rise in the number of COVID-19 cases in the Seoul metropolitan area lately, after a cluster infection broke out at a Coupang distribution center in Bucheon, Gyeonggi-do Province.
According to the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention on Friday, 160 out of the 181 community infections from May 21st to May 27th came from the metropolitan area.

"In the past week, confirmed patients in the Seoul metropolitan area accounted for 88.4 percent of the community infections. The latest cluster infections started from clubs and bars, singing rooms, religious events, restaurants, workplaces or private academies."

All 58 new cases that South Korea reported on Friday were in the metropolitan area20 in Seoul, another 20 in Gyeonggi-do Province, and 18 in Incheon.
Only three were imported cases and the rest were community transmissions.
The KCDC said a total of 102 confirmed cases have been linked to the Bucheon logistics center as of Friday noon.
Of those, 72 were Coupang employees and 30 were secondary infections.
The KCDC also said that the virus has been detected in equipment at the logistics center, such as keyboards or computer mouses used in the workshop, or safety helmets which are shared by workers.
The KCDC raised the possibility that it may have been dead viruses that were detected, but stressed the need to sterilize more thoroughly, as COVID-19 had been found even after the company implemented disinfection measures.
Meanwhile, cases linked to Itaewon clubs and bars in the nation had reached 266 as of Friday noon.
South Korea had a total of 11,402 cases by the end of Thursday, and 2-hundred-69 deaths.
Kim Jae-hee, Arirang News.
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea reports 58 new COVID-19 cases on Friday; all in Seoul metropolitan area
Updated: 2020-05-29 17:02:37 KST

contents.context:
As new COVID-19 outbreaks flare with the easing of high intensity social distancing restrictions, South Korea plans to request imports of Gilead's anti-viral drug remdesivir to treat COVID-19.
The Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Friday that they will seek import approval from the nation's food and drug safety ministry as a government panel has concluded that remdesivir showed positive results and since there are no other anti-viral medication proven effective just yet.
Remdesivir was originally developed to treat Ebola, but has been found to cut hospital stay by 31-percent and reduce the fatality rate of COVID-19 infected patients by about five percentage points.
Reporter : peterwjchoi@gmail.com
contents.headline:
S. Korean regulator to consider Remdesivir to treat COVID-19
Updated: 2020-05-29 17:02:14 KST

contents.context:
Seoul has confirmed that the South Korean military and the U.S. Forces Korea did transport missiles and other items in the early hours of Friday to the U.S. base in Seongju County - home to the THAAD missile defense system - to replace worn out equipment there.
Seoul's defense ministry, however, denied speculations that it was a covert move to install more launchers.
The items brought in include THAAD guided missiles, power generators, electronic data collection equipment, and air conditioning and heating equipment for troops.
South Korea did notify China, which has long opposed the presence of the anti-missile system here - in advance.
The USFK said the operation was a regular resupply to support the allies' defense posture.
Reporter : jiyeonkim@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Military transports replacement equipment to U.S. THAAD base in Seongju
Updated: 2020-05-29 17:00:14 KST

contents.context:
Starting next month, South Korea's public distribution system for masks will allow face masks to be bought any day of the week.
Until now, everyone had an assigned day depending on their year of birth.
The Ministry of Food and Drug Safety said the general public will be allowed three masks per week, while students under 18 can buy up to five now that they're going back to school.
Pharmacies and other vendors will still check ID cards to enforce the limits.
Mask supplies have now stabilized with South Korea producing almost 15 million a day four times the number it had back in December.
And with the weather heating up, the government is planning to double the number of dental-type masks, which are thinner, and consider exports as well.
Reporter : tommyjang@arirang.com
contents.headline:
S. Korea to ease mask-buying rules in June
Updated: 2020-05-29 14:46:37 KST

contents.context:
South Korea reported 79 new cases of COVID-19 on Thursday, 72 of which were community-based transmissions.
This is the first time in 53 days that there were more than 70 in a single day.
Such a figure comes following a cluster infection at a Coupang distribution center, one of South Korea's largest e-commerce companies, in Bucheon, Gyeonggi-do Province, a satellite city 25 kilometers outside of Seoul.
Gyeonggi-do Province reported Thursday a total of 86 cases linked to the Bucheon logistics center, the first ones five days ago.
Health authorities say this outbreak could see several degrees of transmission since there have already been secondary infections among the families and friends of employees.
So far, at least 19 people who were in close contact with the infected employees have contracted the virus.
As this cluster infection comes as South Korea reopens its schools, the government has taken stronger quarantine measures to stop link transmissions spreading further.
It announced that public facilities like parks and museums will be closed for two weeks starting this Friday in Seoul, Incheon and the surrounding province of Gyeonggi-do.
Also, entertainment facilities, like bars and clubs, are advised to close until June 14th, and social distancing measures will be strengthened if the situation isn't brought under control in the next two weeks.

"In order to stop the virus from spreading in the metropolitan area, it's very important how we handle the next two weeks. If the outbreak continues to grow, we'll have no choice but to go back to strong social distancing."

The Gyeonggi-do Provincial Office has ordered a two-week shutdown of Coupang's logistics centers in Bucheon and Goyang, where an additional case was confirmed.
Choi Jeong-yoon, Arirang News.
Reporter : jychoi@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Cluster infection linked to S. Korea logistics center grows to over 80
Updated: 2020-05-29 10:06:40 KST

contents.context:
This is Yeouido High School in Seoul.
Usually bustling with students, but today there are none in sight.
This is because an instructor at a nearby cram school was confirmed to have been infected with COVID-19.
Seven other schools in the area also closed, and quarantine authorities moved in to disinfect the schools.
Another middle school in Seoul has closed, after one of its students was found to have been infected by a family member who worked at the e-commerce logistics center in Bucheon, just west of Seoul.
As a result of these sporadic community infections, 838 schools and kindergartens are now closed, and their re-opening will be delayed.
By region, Bucheon, Gyeonggi-do Province, where the Coupang logistics center is located, has the largest number of closed schools at 251, followed by 243 in Incheon,. 182 in Gumi, Gyeongsangbuk-do Province, and 117 in Seoul.
In particular, 284 schools in Bucheon, Incheon's Bupyeong-gu District and Gyeyang-gu Districts have been closed due to the cluster infection at the logistics center.

"Using a new method of alternating between both remote and in-school classes, we will adjust the number of students in school, in order to minimize density."

On Wednesday, with the second phase of the re-opening of schools and kindergartens, the attendance rate was almost 90-and-a-half percent.
However, that number will surely drop significantly, as more parents opt to keep their kids at home due to the reemergence of cluster infections around the nation.
Lee Seung-jae, Arirang News.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Schools, kindergartens delay re-opening due to community COVID-19 cases
Updated: 2020-05-29 10:06:39 KST

contents.context:
President Moon Jae-in will chair a session of the emergency economic council next Monday to discuss the government's proposed third extra COVID-19-related budget.
Another topic is South Korea's economic policy direction for the second half of 2020.
President Moon last chaired the council meeting about a month ago.
Over five sessions, President Moon unveiled stimulus measures worth some 80 billion U.S. dollars to help companies and people cope with the crisis.
His chairing of Monday's meeting is likely to show the importance of the extra budget, and lay out the specifics of the so-called Korea New Deal.
Reporter : kimmj@arirang.com
contents.headline:
President Moon to chair emergency economic council to discuss extra budget plan
Updated: 2020-05-29 09:55:46 KST

contents.context:
We start with the latest coronavirus figures in South Korea.
The country reported 58 new cases on Friday, …amid cluster infections at a logistics center on the outskirts of Seoul.
Of them, 55 were community transmissions, …with 19 detected in Seoul, 18 in Gyeonggi-do Province …and 18 in Incheon.
Three were imported.
The total number of cases is eleven,four-hundred-two.
There were no new deaths, …keeping the death toll at two-hundred-69.
Over 24-thousand people are being tested, …and 23 more have been discharged after making full recoveries.
Meanwhile, South Korea is set to phase out its five-day rotation system for buying face masks at pharmacies starting in June.
People can now buy three masks any day of the week, and the purchase limit for citizens under 18 years of age has been increased to five to ensure they are safe at school.
Reporter :
contents.headline:
S. Korea reports 58 new COVID-19 cases on Friday, no new deaths
Updated: 2020-05-29 09:55:30 KST

contents.context:
South Korea's Prime Minister Chung Sye-kyun stressed the importance of using Big Data to plan for the future.

"We are living in the age of uncertainty. Uncertainty caused by the COVID-19 outbreak is one of the main examples. Big Data is our weapon in preparing for an uncertain future."

Speaking at the '2020 South Korea Future Forecast Symposium', the Prime Minister vowed that the government will implement a Korean version of the 'Digital New Deal', and strive to nurture new technologies like Big Data, Artificial Intelligence, blockchains and bio-medicine.
Also at the symposium, one economic expert forecasts that globalization is regressing due to the COVID-19 pandemic, and said this will lead to the end of the dominance of the U.S.

"The main change in the post-COVID-19 era will be "de-globalization". There will be changes in the global value chain. Digitalization and non-contact life will expand, and the weakened dominance of the U.S. will open up the G0 era."

There was also a special session focused on the pandemic.
One expert from the International Vaccine Institute stressed the need to use data to pull forward the lagging COVID-19 vaccine development in South Korea.

"Unlike diagnosis and quarantine, South Korea is far behind in vaccine development. But I believe there are still plenty of opportunities. We can use data that's already out to come up with a better strategy."

He added that at least 10 institutions and companies in South Korea are working on developing a vaccine, and he believes around two of them will start clinical trials in June.
He said he predicts vaccines to be available by early next year.

"Thursday's event was also broadcast live online,… as part of social distancing efforts amid the COVID-19 outbreak.
Kim Jae-hee, Arirang News."
Reporter : jhee@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Experts gather to forecast future of S. Korea on Thursday
Updated: 2020-05-28 17:09:32 KST
